title: Monday, 14th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Okay, let's get on. Welcome to Monday. Welcome to Markets Live.

BE

Today's portrait, then.

BE

11:05 am
BE

A still from this really excellent Bloomberg Businessweek profile: https://www.bloomb...2015-steve-bannon/

BE

Which gives a good insight into the thinking of the Potus-elect's special adviser.

BE

https://www.ft.com...-a0bb-97f42551dbf4

11:07 am
undefined
BE

So anyway. Paul's on a train, apparently, so you have me solo for a bit.

BE

And we're back into "hey look, Treasuries yields are up so let's just buy stuff"

11:09 am
Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 208.75, up 7 (+3.47%), High: 209.25, Low: 204.20, Volume: 19.98m
Legal & General Group PLC (LGEN:LSE): Last: 238.80, up 8.9 (+3.87%), High: 238.90, Low: 231.20, Volume: 7.02m
BE

(@SoS: I was undecided between the two.)

11:09 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 208.80, up 7.2 (+3.57%), High: 209.30, Low: 203.30, Volume: 7.09m
Prudential PLC (PRU:LSE): Last: 1,522, up 44 (+2.98%), High: 1,523, Low: 1,490, Volume: 1.50m
BE

In amongst those we have a few stories, though.

11:10 am
BE

Starting, for want of alternatives, with M&S.

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 339.30, up 12.1 (+3.70%), High: 341.20, Low: 331.60, Volume: 3.64m
BE

Citi's gone positive.

11:11 am
BE

Largely on the argument that M&S is hugely flabby (which we know) so it can cut costs (which is something it's historically failed to do, hence the flabbiness).

BE

A central part of the argument seems to be that M&S can close down its office at 5 Merchant Square

BE

(Which'd be moderately bad news for the Reubens and the Jarvises, whose JV owns the Paddington Basin.)

11:12 am
BE

Rent's 8% of central costs, and 5 Merchant Square's more than a quarter of that ....

BE

BE

Second, stripping back the duplicate functions in (for example) the online business, which is apparently being run as a separate company at the moment.

11:13 am
PM

(hi)

BE

... All of which looks familiar stuff, really. We've been talking about radical M&S cost cutting then being underwhelmed by each multi-year strategic review for approximately four decades.

BE

Nevertheless, here's the top line.

11:13 am
BE

We remain cautious about MKS’s strategy to sustainably reignite sales growth, but 1/We are more confident about delivery on the UK store plan, 2/See opportunity on central cost savings, 3/See encouraging signs around full price clothing sales and 4/This is despite the increased cash costs FCF yield is 6.5% in FY18E and 11% in FY19E with a dividend yield of 6%. With the stock down c7% since the strategy update, investor concerns look overdone.

BE

Execution remains a key risk
Our Buy rating is predicated on MKS being able to deliver on its strategic elements whilst maintaining its returns within the Food business. But we see limited downside to the shares at this level and upside from potential upgrades of c25% over the medium term if MKS delivers.

BE

Our forecasts continue to assume a more subdued UK demand environment
Our FY17 PBT forecast remains unchanged at £608m. For FY18 we increase forecasts by c4% reflecting half the benefit from the International loss elimination and continue to forecast UK Clothing & Home LFL -3.5% with gross margins -75bp. We don’t factor in anything from the UK store plan or potential costs savings. Our forecast agenda points to a -14%, EPS decline in FY17E and -11% in FY18E. Versus consensus we are now only c6-7% below vs 10% below previously.

11:14 am
BE

We estimate incremental EBIT of £80m could be achievable over the medium term from UK store restructuring
Driven through store churn, new openings and little benefit from sales transfers on closures and with minimal change in the revenue base given productivity benefits. However this programme is spread over 5 years, requires £250m of capital investment and visibility on phasing remains low.

BE

On top of this we still see scope for further Head Office savings of c£60m
This mainly relates to consolidation of its two HOs in Paddington and integration of the online business into central teams with the balance from streamlining marketing and retail occupancy costs. At £615m pa, MKS’s UK central cost base is vast and of similar quantum to group PBT. We estimate cash costs of c£157m to achieve this.

BE

New TP 365p
Reflects mid-point between fair value based on 11x FY19E EV/EBIT on our current forecast agenda (340p) and potential valuation if costs savings and benefits are delivered assuming the same multiple, discounted back (390p). Implied FY19E EV/EBIT multiple is 12.0x, PE of 13.2x, dividend yield of 6%.

11:14 am
PM

Don't they have, like, 13 head offices or something?

PM

Not just the two in Paddington

BE

7 head offices. And, yes, two in Paddington.

11:15 am
PM

7 omg smile

BE

Though one could argue that it's one office in Paddington that's split between two campuses.

BE

I seem to remember we got very excited about the cost benefit of them moving out of Baker Street.

11:16 am
BE

Moving folk to places like Nottingham, Stockley Park and Hemel Hempstead.

BE

Anyway, Waterside House (the actual HQ) is leased until 2028. So that stays, one assumes.

BE

Digging in further to the note, and trying not to be reactively cynical, it does seem to be a "cut the right costs without losing the right customers" argument.

11:18 am
BE

c10% of M&S customers account for c50% of sales in both Food and Clothing.

PM

Blimey

BE

Sacking people's difficult and keeping continuity is difficult, tho. Even when the people really should be sacked. See STAN, for instance.

11:19 am
undefined
PM

These bond market moves

PM

Sea of red, prices wise

11:20 am
PM

US 10 eyar moved 1.5%, price was

PM

Yielding 2.28 currently

PM

Its across the board tho

11:21 am
PM

Hey, we've got some Buiter

PM

He seems to be saying this was always going to happen

PM

No black swan event

11:21 am
PM

The election of Donald Trump as the 45th President of the United States has set the media alight. The outcome has been treated as a tremendous surprise, although one might be forgiven for wondering how any outcome to an election or referendum of any type can be called a surprise these days.

Of course the outcome was not expected if we look at the opinion polls, even less so by most of the commentators, who were generally putting the probability of a Trump win somewhere in the region of 25-45%. However the reaction in markets over the past few days suggests that investors have learnt from recent experiences and were, for the most part, looking beyond headlines and sentiment.

Yes, we have seen bond yields rise sharply, and there have been some sizeable moves in foreign exchange markets, but these do not look like knee-jerk reactions to a sudden shock. They look far more consistent with a shift in expectations that was to be expected once we got clarification of the result of an election that featured far more polarised policy implications than any other event we have seen in a major economy in recent times. It is very possible that we would have seen moves of a similar magnitude had Hillary Clinton won, just not in the same direction.

PM

We have argued on many occasions that "black-swan" events do not really drive markets on a sustained basis. We continue to believe that it is unexpected outcomes to expected events that cause major market re-pricings, when they have a significant impact on the direction of the underlying trends in market drivers.

The election of Donald Trump to the Presidency is not a "black-swan" event. Far from it; it was always a very real possibility in a tight (effectively) two-horse race. However his sometimes unconventional, and often challenging, policy proposals have the potential to have a major impact on the global political and macroeconomic landscape.

We may now be on the verge of the most significant shift in the macro environment since the global financial crisis. We have spent almost a decade in a secular period of slow but steady growth, uniform policy and suppressed volatility. All that looks like changing now with policy shifting to a far more diversified basis.

PM

And I see UBS have chosen today to publish their 2017 outlook

11:22 am
PM

Which is basically a shrug

BE

It's only mid November!

PM

Good morning, today Arend Kapteyn, Chief Economist for UBS Investment Bank, published our Investment Bank Economic Outlook for 2017-2018.

He and his team feel the Outlook for next year is unusually uncertain and see significant upside and downside risks - many of which the market is not prepared for.

11:23 am
PM

Do you want the cover page?

BE

Sure, why not.

PM

ok

11:23 am
PM

Continuity or Discontinuity?
Our baseline is for nominal global growth to increase for the first time in seven years…

Baselines never materialize because they are modal rather than probabilistic, and so don't incorporate the inevitable tail risk events. But our baseline is for nominal global growth to increase for the first time in seven years (real growth up from 3.1% to 3.5%), driven by above-consensus growth in the US, a recovery in oil-sector-related investment, and several large emerging markets emerging from recession. This is not a story of great optimism – mostly a modest improvement in investment, which has been contributing only a third as much to GDP growth relative to its pre-GFC contribution. And the rebound in EM is extremely narrow. Brazil, Russia and Argentina explain almost the entire EM growth improvement and Brazil's contribution to the increase in global growth is almost as large as the US, despite having a GDP weight that is only one-sixth the size.

PM

…but unusual levels of uncertainty about policies and outcomes

The outlook is unusually uncertain given political developments in the US and Europe, the degree to which 'monetary space' to be accommodative gets reduced by (projected) higher inflation and growth, and the market's reaction to likely tapering by the ECB and BoJ.

PM

What could go right? US fiscal/tax, Banks, China and Europe

- A large fiscal spending/tax package in the US that is not neutralized by disruptive trade policy could lift global growth (Trump's pre-election plans suggest 20bp extra US growth annually, with some upside if the composition of the package changes to income groups with higher fiscal multipliers, and downside if it runs into implementation constraints).

- Banks have cut 40-50% of GDP out of their balance sheets and that process appears to be nearing completion (see the section "is the end of the debt super-cycle approaching?"). It's possible that helps further unclog the credit channel.

- We have embedded policy-induced slowing in the property sector in China into our baseline, and political uncertainty-induced slowing into our Eurozone baseline. We could be wrong on both.

11:24 am
PM

What could go wrong? Oil, end of QE, protectionism

- The market is priced for an extrapolation of the 'low for longer' environment with zero monetary policy normalization (on average) in 2017. We show that a two-standard-deviation shock in oil prices to the upside would lead to a very significant overshooting of central bank inflation targets (in DM) and induce a 2013-like sell-off in fixed income, equity and EMFX markets.

- Although G3 central bank balance sheets aren't projected to decline in aggregate until 2020 (the Fed should start to passively roll off in 2018), the net additional injection of liquidity coming from QE programs should peak next month (December 2016) and then progressively decline. It is unclear how the market will adjust to the simultaneous reduction in liquidity support and a potentially large increase in US debt issuance.

- Creeping protectionism has so far explained only 7% of the global trade slowdown. But there is potential for more overt trade disputes and a dismantling of free trade agreements.

PM

There's 200 pages of it

PM

Suppose we can start an oulook post in the usual place

11:24 am
PM

However!

PM

We are close to deploying AV2

PM

And when we do, the Long Room will have to close for a few weeks while it gets rebuilt

11:25 am
PM

So I will get some early Outlooks up -- and then you'll have to wait till mid December for the rest

PM

Sorry

BE

Hm. I feel uncomfortable about getting 2017 outlooks already.

11:25 am
BE

Given the multitude of things that have gone wrong already in 2016, I fear we shouldn't underestimate the possible things that could still go wrong in the remaining 12th of the year.

PM

This is true

undefined
11:26 am
BE

So, Greencore mentioned on the right.

Greencore Group PLC (GNC:LSE): Last: 330.10, up 38.2 (+13.09%), High: 333.50, Low: 297.80, Volume: 1.32m
BE

Big US acquisition.

11:27 am
BE

Peacock Foods. (It makes sandwiches, not food for peacocks.)

BE

£594m, funded by a £439m rights.

BE

It's a supplier to Kraft, Dole & Tyson.

11:28 am
BE

Sept 2016 sales +15%, EBITDA +34%

BE

Let me get some Peel Hunt to walk us through the detail.

BE

The business has been acquired on 10.4x EBITDA, which
reduces to 8.5x including the anticipated $15m of synergies. The
acquisition is expected to be significantly earnings enhancing.
Greencore has also brought forward its full-year results. Full-year
EBIT increased by 11.2% to £102m vs our forecast of £101.6m,
with EPS +8.3% to 19.5p. Net debt of £332m (2.4x
ND/EBITDA) was lower than our £348m forecast.
This acquisition transforms the shape of the group, resolves the
issues in the US and brings a significant new growth
opportunity. The terms of the deal look sensible. At first sight,
this looks like a deal that should be well received. We like what
we see so far and have upgraded our recommendation from Add
to Buy.

11:29 am
PM

Rights is 9-for-13

BE

The business supplies a wide range range of ambient, frozen & chilled
convenience food products, including breakfast sandwiches and kids meals for a
range of customers. The business model is typically cost plus, with a pass through
agreement on both ingredients and labour. Investment in new facilities are
generally on a co-investment model. As a result, ROI should be attractive,
though margin upside is limited. Peacock’s customers include KraftHeinz, Dole,
Kellogg’s, Gerber, General Mills & Apio. The relationships with the top-seven
customers are on average greater than 15 years.

PM

At 153p

11:29 am
PM

Why underwrite at that discount?

BE

"Breakfast sandwiches" ... Because 'Murca.

PM

Free money for....

11:30 am
PM

The Rights Issue has been fully underwritten by HSBC Bank plc ("HSBC"), Goodbody Stockbrokers UC ("Goodbody"), Jefferies International Limited ("Jefferies"), and Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. ("Rabobank") (together, the "Underwriters").

BE

I guess the underwriting fees are exceptionally low at that discount, or I hope they would be.

BE

That's usually the explanation I get when I ask. "We underwrite a 50% discount or whatever because the cost of doing so is negligible."

11:31 am
BE

Back to Peel Hunt.

BE

Hope you all had a good weekend -- or at least used it to take a break from the actual open sewer that each day's news has become.

BE

Everyone else is restricted, I think. Goodbody, HSBC and Jefferies would otherwise publish, but it's just rote today.

11:33 am
BE

Oh! Berenberg. They'll do.

BE

......... actually, they won't as they haven't sent me it yet. Never mind. Enough sandwiches.

11:35 am
BE

Anso on the acquisition frond, we have Playtech.

Playtech PLC (PTEC:LSE): Last: 919.50, up 37 (+4.19%), High: 924.00, Low: 886.00, Volume: 640.19k
PM

http://www.investe...1611140700120652P/

11:35 am
BE

Buying Consolidated Financial for up to $120m

PM

Straight Through Processing ("STP") brokerage which provides retail brokers with multi-asset execution, prime brokerage services, liquidity and complementary risk management tools

BE

Yep, it's continuing Playtech's move from being a bookie facilitator in some tricky territories to being a financial punting platform.

11:36 am
PM

CFH has proven technological capabilities and generates revenue primarily from trading volume processed through its brokerage platform, either as clearing fees or technology services. It currently has over 400 customers and partners worldwide in more than 80 countries, which service thousands of retail customers worldwide, and is considered one of the largest and most reputable B2B providers for technology and clearing in the industry.

BE

Important line ................

BE

CFH's wholly owned subsidiary, CFH Clearing Limited ("CFH Clearing") is regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (the "FCA") and Playtech confirms that regulatory approval has been received.

11:37 am
PM

Actually, this thing has some blue blooded clients: Barclays, Goldman Sachs, UBS, Jefferies and BNP Paribas.

PM

But sorry, go on

BE

Yup. You'll remember there were some concerns around the Plus500 bid about whether the FCA was too comfortable with Playtech

11:38 am
BE

This acquisition, and that line in the statement, would seem to nail those concerns.

BE

Canaccord's enthusiastic, as Canaccord often is.

BE

Playtech has announced the maximum €110m acquisition of CFH, a technology specialist in the Online Financial trading market, in a deal which should significantly enhance Playtech's B2B capabilities in its Financials division. CFH has over 400 customers globally and provides liquidity control (matching online retail broking trades with liquidity provided by a long list of tier one banks), it provides price feeds and a range of risk management tools. It provides liquidity in around 110 instruments, and currently matches $100bn in transactional volumes per month. It gets paid primarily through transaction fees directly related to customer volumes. CFH is regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), and the FCA has approved Playtech's acquisition of the business.
CFH generated €17.6m of revenues and €5.2m of Ebitda in FY15 and is growing rapidly. PTEC is paying an initial €39.8m cash for a 70% stake (valuing the business at c.7x Ebitda, which implies an €8.2m Ebitda run rate). There is an option to acquire the remaining 30% in 2019 on a 6x Ebitda multiple.

11:39 am
BE

Impact on Canaccord Genuity view
PTEC is acquiring a fast growing technology business which considerably strengthens its ability to develop a B2B Online Financials business. PTEC can significantly expand the number of products traded by CFH (Markets.com trades in over 600 instruments), it can cross sell its B2B trading platform to CFH's significant customer list and it should be able to negotiate improved terms with liquidity providers, reflecting the greater scale of the enlarged group.
We see the transaction as immediately Earnings enhancing, and it should generate a double-digit first year return on investment. We leave our FY16 forecasts unchanged, but FY17 Ebitda rises from €364.9m to €374.5m, with EPS 2% from 33.7c to 34.5c. FY18 Ebitda rises from €395.5m to €407.4m, with EPS +3% to 36.9c. Details are on page 3.
However, as the trading update confirmed last week, there will be some negative impact from recent weakness in the £ and Asian currencies (although much of this is clawed back through the £-denominated share price), and also the impact of softer volumes on Markets.com.
Valuation
Playtech shares are trading on a FY17 cash-adjusted PER of just 10.5x and an EV/Ebitda of 9.1x, backed by a dividend yield of 3.4%. We think this is attractive for a market leading technology supplier to a structural growth markets and we see the CFH transaction transforming its B2B capabilities in the adjacent Online Financials trading market, providing a significant additional growth vertical. We raise our TP from 1125p to 1140p, putting the shares on a 12.0x FY17 EV/Ebitda and 14.0x cash adjusted PER. BUY.

BE

And Liberum.

BE

(PTEC LN) Playtech today announces it has agreed to acquire Consolidated Financial Holdings A/S a technology company with products including a leading Straight Through Processing (“STP”) brokerage which provides retail brokers with multi-asset execution, prime brokerage services, liquidity and complementary risk management tools.

This looks like another diversifying deal and Management expect the addition to give Playtech customers better scale processing and trading capability in their Financials Division. Revenue and adjusted EBITDA generated for the year ended 31 December 2015 was $19.2m and $5.7m.

Playtech will pay up to $120m which management estimate is a c6-7x the EBITDA run-rate. In terms of wider Group trading as stated last week at the time of Playtech’s event for investors and analysts, Management comment that the Financials division has seen very positive signs of improvement in first time depositors and active customers in H2 2016 although overall performance has been impacted by low market volatility (that may change in Q4 post the US election).

Given the offsetting backdrop in Q3 and the earnings enhancement of this deal we would not expect any major changes to consensus forecasts.

11:41 am
BE

UBS too.

BE

We see the deal as 3% EBITDA accretive (2016E), but imagine investors could attach a premium rating to the uplift given the earnings are 100% regulated and in the B2B space, with an attractive transaction driven revenue model. An EV/EBITDA multiple of 7-13x compares with Playtech at 10x, we calculate.

BE

Fairly sensible gambit, this. Take money from unregulated gambling and churn it into regulated financial stuff.

11:41 am
undefined
BE

Back to retail then.

BE

And Tesco. Up a tad.

11:43 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 202.20, up 3.75 (+1.89%), High: 205.20, Low: 201.90, Volume: 9.02m
BE

HSBC pushing.

BE

David Mccarthy, of course, who seems well followed.

11:44 am
BE

When we downgraded Tesco to Hold (DEFCON 1: Be prepared, a price war may be coming, 6 July 2016) we were clear this was due to a concern that ASDA might undertake a major price repositioning. We were also clear that we saw Tesco as the long-term winner and we stand by our previous analysis on its significant underlying economic advantages (The long-term winner is increasingly apparent, 5 October 2016). We still expect ASDA to get more aggressive on price (what else can it do?) but the pace of the Tesco recovery is increasing, meaning it is better able to cope with whatever ASDA does.

BE

The Capital Markets Day on 16 November is likely to focus on long-term potential and to give more detail on how Tesco expects to deliver a 3.5-4% operating margin. Below we recreate the Tesco chart that highlights the lower margin problems of on-line and general merchandise (GM). The core business is already on its way to a 4% margin and eliminating poor performances in on-line and GM should move it forward.

BE

Recovery gathering pace: Volumes, cash sales and market share are all improving. At the same time, the company is keeping a tight control on costs to ensure the high contribution margin of extra sales falls through to the bottom line, allowing further investment in price. This momentum gives Tesco firepower to defend against ASDA or to fund its own pricing initiatives.

11:44 am
BE

Tesco should be highly cash generative by 2020e, with a UK operating margin of c4%. At this point, we expect the industry will be back to equilibrium, with Tesco having proved the long-term winner. Our previous higher Beta assumption in our DCF valuation had been as a result of perceived price move risks, but with a lower risk of a major ASDA price move impacting Tesco, we bring it back down, moving our TP to 260p from 195p and, with 31% implied upside, we upgrade the stock to Buy from Hold, while our estimates are unchanged.

BE

.. So, that.

Centamin PLC (CEY:LSE): Last: 136.10, down 5 (-3.54%), High: 142.00, Low: 133.10, Volume: 6.05m
BE

Let's have Credit Suisse on the miners to help pass the time.

BE

THE WEEK THAT WAS: Global mining surged last week, significantly outperforming global markets. The sectors two main earnings
drivers copper and iron ore were both up over 10%. Coal prices remained elevated with thermal coal forward prices remaining
above $100/t and coking coal above $300/t despite the NDRC saying the current relaxation of production restrictions will continue
until spring 2017. Notably, copper prices, the laggard commodity of the year, rebounded strongly with exchange inventory also down
sharply (exchange inventory down 7% over the week). Base metal speculative positioning has also turned m ore positive
particularly in copper and aluminium. Iron ore port inventory fell 2% over the week
KEY THEME – Reflation and rotation, global m ining spot valuation com parison: Trump’s surprise election last week led to
rising bond yields and expectations over higher US infrastructure spend in the years ahead (US public infrastructure investment as a
% of GDP is currently at decade lows). A rise in inflation expectations is historically very positive for commodities and mining
equities, however, the market continues to price in a significant correction in commodity prices next year. On the next slide we
introduce our global m ining spot valuation sum m ary which we will publish each week. At spot prices the large cap miners
are trading on 2-4x EV/EBITDA and FCF yields of over 15%. Perhaps unsurprisingly, companies with heavy coking coal exposure
(Anglo, Teck) are trading on the cheapest spot multiples.

11:31 am
BE

The company forecasts $15m of synergies and there is likely to be a site closure.
The implementation costs are expected to be $20m.
The deal is to be financed by a £439m rights issue (9 for 13 at 153p) and £200m
of new debt facilities at a 3.5% coupon.
This is a transformative deal for Greencore, which establishes the US as a
material contributor to group profits and growth. The transaction price looks
sensible, particularly given Peacock’s growth potential and low risk business
model.
